intro.title: What is GOD LIFE?
intro.content1: GOD LIFE MAKER has a philosophy behind the 'God Life.'
intro.content2: Whether you live the ultimate life or your own life is your freedom.
intro.content3: But if you want to live the God Life, you must visit this site every single morning as soon as you wake up.
intro.content5: This tool is the most extreme, yet most compromised, and most realistic weapon.
intro.content6: There will be no further updates.
intro.content8: The moment you fear failure, your dream disappears.
intro.content9: The stronger your dream becomes, the less you will fear failure.
intro.content10: If you are obsessed with your dream, you will act even knowing you might fail.
intro.content11: I believe living a life obsessed with such a dream is what [GOD LIFE] truly means.

success.title: Success Code (100 Days)
success.subtitle: The Compound Effect of Small Wins
success.description:
Success Code is a system for recording small wins daily over 100 days. Why exactly 100 days? This number has scientific backing.

According to James Clear's bestseller 'Atomic Habits', the key to habit formation isn't repetition count but 'emotional encoding.' Our brain's basal ganglia automates repetitive behaviors, and emotions play a decisive catalytic role in this process. When you record small wins daily and feel that sense of achievement, your brain recognizes this behavior as 'rewarding' and progressively automates it.

Dr. BJ Fogg (Director of Stanford's Behavior Design Lab) found in his 'Tiny Habits' research that habits form when three elements converge: motivation, ability, and trigger. Success Code perfectly satisfies all three: a clear motivation of completing 100 days, a low barrier of just 1 minute daily, and a consistent trigger of recording at the same time each day.

Why 100 days? Dr. Phillippa Lally's research at UCL (University College London) shows that new habits take an average of 66 days to automate, but complex behaviors can require up to 254 days. 100 days is sufficient time for most habits to solidify.

How to Use:
1. Set one goal you want to achieve daily for 100 days
2. Record whether you practiced that goal each day
3. Leave a short note about your feelings and learnings
4. Start a new project when you complete 100 days

The key is 'consistency' not 'perfection.' Don't give up if you miss a day. Research shows missing one day doesn't significantly impact habit formation. What matters is starting again the next day.
success.source: James Clear, Atomic Habits (2018) / BJ Fogg, Tiny Habits (2019) / Phillippa Lally, UCL Habit Formation Study (2009)

discipline.title: Discipline Mastery
discipline.subtitle: Building the Willpower Muscle
discipline.description:
Discipline Mastery is a system for performing 'things you don't want to do but must do' daily. This isn't a simple checklist. It's training that physically changes your brain.

Professor Andrew Huberman (Stanford Neurobiology) shared groundbreaking research in his 2023 podcast. A brain region called the 'anterior mid-cingulate cortex (aMCC)' activates and grows when you 'do things you don't want to do.' This region is more developed in centenarians, extreme athletes, and people with strong willpower.

The remarkable finding is that this region can grow regardless of age. Performing slightly uncomfortable tasks daily physically enlarges the aMCC. Conversely, doing only comfortable things shrinks it. David Goggins' (former Navy SEAL, ultramarathon runner) advice to 'seek discomfort' was scientifically accurate.

Professor Roy Baumeister's (Florida State University) 'ego depletion' theory states that willpower is like a muscle. It fatigues temporarily when used but becomes stronger after recovery. Discipline Mastery leverages this principle.

How to Use:
1. Set 5-13 rules to follow daily
2. Maintain a difficulty level that's neither too easy nor too hard
3. Must include 'things you don't want to do' (e.g., cold showers, morning exercise, digital device limits)
4. Check daily and monitor your achievement rate
5. Strengthen rules when 90%+ achievement becomes easy

Caution: Don't set too many rules initially. Research shows attempting only 3 or fewer new habits at once is effective. Start small and gradually increase. The goal isn't 'doing everything perfectly' but 'becoming slightly better than yesterday.'
discipline.source: Andrew Huberman, Huberman Lab Podcast (2023) / David Goggins, Can't Hurt Me (2018) / Roy Baumeister, Willpower (2011) / Anterior Mid-Cingulate Cortex Research, Nature Neuroscience

destiny.title: Destiny Navigator
destiny.subtitle: Give Purpose to Your Time
destiny.description:
Destiny Navigator isn't just a scheduling tool. It's a life design system connecting 'your ultimate self' to 'today's goals.' It consists of 10-level long-term perspective and 24-hour time blocks.

According to Professor Cal Newport's (Georgetown University Computer Science) 'Deep Work,' people who use time blocking accomplish twice as much high-quality work in the same time as those who don't. Why? The brain expends energy every time it makes a 'decision.' This is called 'decision fatigue.'

Roy Baumeister's research shows people make approximately 35,000 decisions daily, each consuming mental energy. Planning your schedule in the morning effectively handles hundreds of 'what should I do now?' decisions at once.

Benjamin Franklin, starting in 1726 (at age 21), would wake at 5 AM daily to plan 'what good shall I do this day?' and reflect each night on 'what good have I done today?' He maintained this habit for 58 years until age 84. His schedule is the prototype of modern time blocking.

The 10-Level Long-term Perspective System:
1. Ultimate Self: Who do I want to become before I die?
2. Me in 10 Years: Where will I be in 10 years?
3. Me in 5 Years: What's the biggest goal to achieve in 5 years?
4. 3 Years/1 Year/6 Months/3 Months/1 Month/2 Weeks/1 Week: Progressively concrete goals
5. Today's Goal: What must I do today?

The core of this system is 'backward goal setting.' Starting from ultimate goals, you derive what to do today. This way, daily actions connect to life goals.

24-Hour Time Block Usage:
1. Plan in 30-minute units from wake time to bedtime
2. Distinguish 'deep work' time (focused tasks) from 'shallow work' time (simple tasks)
3. Always designate rest time as blocks too
4. Compare with actual activities at day's end
5. Analyze differences and apply to next day's planning
destiny.source: Cal Newport, Deep Work (2016) / Benjamin Franklin, Autobiography (1791) / Roy Baumeister, Decision Fatigue Research / Stephen Covey, 7 Habits of Highly Effective People

epistle.title: Self Epistle
epistle.subtitle: The Neuroscience of Gratitude and Reflection
epistle.description:
Self Epistle is a system for writing letters to 'yesterday's me' and 'tomorrow's me.' This isn't a simple diary. It's the most effective mental health tool proven by cutting-edge neuroscience.

The Neuroscience of Gratitude:
UC Berkeley Greater Good Science Center research shows gratitude writing activates the prefrontal cortex and increases dopamine and serotonin release. Indiana University's 2017 fMRI study found that groups who wrote gratitude letters maintained elevated prefrontal activity even 3 months later.

Professor Robert Emmons' (UC Davis) 10-year research shows people who record daily gratitudes:
- Feel 25% happier
- Have stronger immunity
- Experience better sleep quality
- Show higher goal achievement rates

The Science of Reflection:
Harvard Business School research shows employees who spent 15 minutes daily reflecting performed 23% better than those who didn't. Reflection strengthens the brain's 'metacognition' ability—the capacity to recognize and regulate your own thinking process.

Self Epistle Structure:

[To Yesterday's Me] - Process the past
- 3 Things Grateful For: What you appreciated today
- 3 Important Things: Meaningful events that happened today
- One Anger: What made you angry and why (emotional awareness)
- 3 Leisure Activities: What you enjoyed today

[To Tomorrow's Me] - Design the future
- 3 Reflections: Things to improve tomorrow
- Free Message: What you want to tell tomorrow's you

Why the 'Letter' Format?
Professor Pennebaker's (University of Texas) research shows expressing emotions in writing reduces cortisol (stress hormone) and improves immune function. The 'letter' format particularly induces deeper self-reflection than monologue. You must explain to 'another you' rather than just 'you.'

Why Only Today and Yesterday Are Writable:
Research shows emotions begin to distort in memory within 48 hours. Recording on the same day or next day enables accurate emotional documentation.
epistle.source: Robert Emmons, Thanks! (2007) / UC Berkeley Greater Good Science Center / Indiana University fMRI Study (2017) / James Pennebaker, Writing to Heal / Harvard Business School Reflection Study (2014)

money.title: Money Flow
money.subtitle: Redefine Your Relationship with Money
money.description:
Money Flow isn't a simple household ledger for recording income and expenses. It's a behavioral economics tool for understanding and improving your 'psychological relationship with money.'

Why Track Money?
Professor Dan Ariely's (Duke University Behavioral Economics) research shows humans systematically make irrational decisions about money. We fall into 'mental accounting' errors. For example, we treasure salary but spend bonuses easily, and we spend more with cards than cash.

The Power of Daily Recording:
Duke University research shows merely recording expenses reduces spending by 15-20% on average. Why? This is the 'observer effect.' When we start measuring something, we become aware of it, and behavior naturally changes.

Professor Richard Thaler's (Nobel Prize in Economics winner) 'Nudge' theory states small environmental changes drive large behavioral changes. Daily expense tracking is a 'nudge to yourself.'

The Psychology of Money:
Behavioral economics has revealed fascinating facts:

1. Pain of Paying: The brain's pain regions activate when paying with cash. Cards dull this pain, inducing overspending.

2. Anchoring: The first price seen becomes the reference point. A $50 shirt next to a $100 shirt feels 'cheap.'

3. Present Bias: We value $100 now more than $1,000 in the future.

How to Use Money Flow:
1. Record all income (salary, bonuses, side income, etc.)
2. Record all expenses by category
3. Check income-expense balance at month's end
4. Analyze patterns: Where do you spend most? What's unnecessary?
5. Set next month's budget

The Importance of Category Classification:
Categorizing expenses helps avoid 'mental accounting' traps. Separating food, transportation, entertainment, etc. clarifies 'what I'm really spending money on.'

What Wealthy People Have in Common:
Thomas Stanley's 'The Millionaire Next Door' research shows self-made millionaires' common trait wasn't 'frugality' but 'awareness.' They knew their financial situation precisely. Daily recording is the first step.
money.source: Dan Ariely, Dollars and Sense (2017) / Richard Thaler, Nudge (2008) / Thomas Stanley, The Millionaire Next Door (1996) / Duke University Expense Tracking Study

bio.title: Bio Hacking
bio.subtitle: Optimize Your Biology
bio.description:
Bio Hacking provides scientific protocols for sleep, exercise, nutrition, and mindset. This isn't a trendy fad. It's proven optimization methods based on cutting-edge neuroscience and physiology.

Sleep Optimization - The Foundation of Everything:
According to Professor Matthew Walker (UC Berkeley, 'Why We Sleep' author), sleep isn't an 'optional luxury' but a 'biological necessity.' Less than 7 hours of sleep:
- Reduces immunity by 70%
- Decreases learning ability by 40%
- Increases mortality risk by 24%

Professor Andrew Huberman's Sleep Protocol:
1. Get sunlight within 30-60 minutes of waking (10-30 min). This triggers cortisol awakening response and schedules melatonin release 16 hours later.
2. Block blue light 2 hours before bed. Blue light suppresses melatonin release.
3. Keep bedroom temperature at 65-67°F (18-19°C). Body temperature drop induces sleep.
4. Wake at the same time daily. Even weekends. Consistent wake times are the foundation of everything.

The Neuroscience of Exercise:
Professor John Ratey's (Harvard Medical School, 'Spark' author) research shows exercise physically changes the brain:
- Increased BDNF (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor): Creates new brain cells
- Enlarged hippocampus: Improves memory
- Activated prefrontal cortex: Enhances focus and decision-making

Minimum Effective Exercise: 3 times weekly, 30 minutes, heart-rate-elevating cardio. This alone significantly improves brain function.

Nutrition Protocol:
Dr. Rhonda Patrick's (FoundMyFitness) research shows:
- Intermittent fasting (16:8): Activates autophagy, promotes cellular regeneration
- Omega-3: 70% of brain cell membranes are fat. Fish rich in DHA recommended
- Gut microbiome: 90% of serotonin is produced in the gut. Consume probiotics and fiber

Mindset Optimization:
Professor Carol Dweck's (Stanford, 'Mindset' author) research shows people with 'growth mindset' accept challenges better and recover faster from failure than those with 'fixed mindset.'

Growth Mindset Training:
- Change 'I can't' to 'I can't yet'
- Focus on process, not outcomes
- Redefine failure as learning opportunity

The Bio Hacking section provides columns summarizing these latest studies. Read, apply, and optimize your biology.
bio.source: Andrew Huberman, Huberman Lab Podcast / Matthew Walker, Why We Sleep (2017) / John Ratey, Spark (2008) / Rhonda Patrick, FoundMyFitness / Carol Dweck, Mindset (2006)
